performance.p: First Performed at the Royal Adelphi Theatre.

list.item: GAVARD—Ditto, with long black curled wig.
COCO COCKLET—Blue jacket, red breeches, blue stockings, buff shoes, flaxen wig.

div.stage: SCENE I — A Swiss village—On R.H. an inn; Sign, “The Rising Sun;” L.H., Lottery office, in front of which is a board, displaying the list of prizes, viz., “65, 11, 40, 16, 28.”— Berguin's house at the back—Mountains and bridge.
Enter Ninette and Rosine from inn.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (L.H.)Well, what is it to me? Cocklet has got a beating, and no doubt he deserved it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (R.H.)You certainly take a great interest in your intended.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Who intends he shall be my intended?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Your father.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: But I am not inclined that he shall be my intended, while there are so many smart young men to look unutterable things at me, and so many handsome soldiers coming home. Do you think I shall make him so unhappy as to make him my worst half? Oh dear, no, Rosine! I love soldiers. It's the delight of my heart to look at their long swords and lovely mustachios!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Perhaps you would not object to my brother? He's a soldier.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Perhaps I should not.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But suppose he has fallen in the wars?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: But what proofs are there?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My father has heard so.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Well, if I can't marry a soldier, I'll die an old maid. I'll never marry.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Never?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Never, never!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Never is a long time.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Not too long for my determination. To live happily, one must be—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh! Marriage is like a—like a beautiful rose.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p:
With plenty of thorns about it, to prick your fingers
occasionally. You can be cheerful—you will marry a soldier—my dashing brother, Victor, of the 20th regiment of cavalry;—while poor I, am condemned to your cousin Cocklet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But fools don't always make the worst husbands.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: But you were to tell me, Rosine, how it was your father allowed your brother to be brought up away from home, and the story of his going into the army, and all that.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: As I know you can keep a secret, I'll tell you one;—he is but my half-brother.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Oh! Well?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: When my father was a young man he fell in love with a very beautiful creature, as you or I may be. His father desired him to marry another; and, as he had not courage to disobey his parent, nor the heart to forget his beautiful creature, he was placed in a very awkward situation.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Very!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: However, he at last married my mother, and the poor beautiful creature, took it so much to heart, she would'nt shew herself to anybody; till at length, people said, they heard strange noises in the cottage, where the beautiful creature lived, like somebody hushing a baby. The fact is, I had a brother, who was brought up about twenty miles from hence, by a person, of the name of Jacquard, a farmer, at Merival, with whom he lived for sixteen years, when he quarrell'd with the farmer's son, and the farmer turned my brother out of doors.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: And without letting him know who he was?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How could he?—he was ignorant of it himself. At length, my mother died, and then, father ventured to enquire about him, when he learnt that he had enlisted in a regiment that was on its march to Poland.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: And if the report that he has fallen should turn out to be a false one, how would any of you be able to know him again, if he ever should return?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The farmer knew the regiment he had enlisted in, and when my father explained the secret, he sent him a certificate detailing all the circumstances of his birth;—so it will not be difficult to recognise him when he produces that.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: And why, until this moment, have you always kept this affair a secret?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Because I am so discreet.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: To be candid with you, I never knew it myself till last night.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: You surprise me!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My father and your father were locked up together in our green parlour. To that room is a door, to that door, there is a key-hole, and to that key-hole was an ear. (You could'nt.) I felt so interested—Hush! Your father.Enter Gavard from inn.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (C.)Rosine, my dear, step and tell your father, if my son arrives this evening, I hope to have the honour of his company to sup with us.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (R.)Do you think he'll arrive by this evening?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: I received his letter, ten days since, from Nantes; so he can't stay much longer.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (L.)Poor fellow!—how impatient I am to see him!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: I'ts ten years ago, since he left us. I declare, we shall scarce know him again. You, Ninette, were not ten years old when he turned soldier.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Quite a little thing—not so high—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: But now, he is to give over fighting, and enter upon a campaign in the field of Hymen. Oh! Rosine, you were a little thing too, when he went away; but you are sure to love him. Tell your father he will be expected, if Victor returns this evening;—but I must into the house again, and see that every thing is comfortable, to receive the dear boy. Exit into Inn.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: How he does love my brother!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: He's a kind-hearted creature!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (singing without)“My arm it is my country's right.”

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Gracious!—what a beautiful voice! (looks out, L.H.U.E.) and as I'm a woman, its a soldier.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Two soldiers, I declare!

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: How delightful!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hush! They must not see us looking at them.Enter Fuzee and Leon L.H.U.E.—Leon observes Ninette as she comes down.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.l: “Gaily for love and fame to fight,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Will you cease, you military nightingale? There's an eye

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There. (points to Ninette)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Pshaw! You must'nt be thinking of the girls now. Look this way—eyes left.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, no, this is our way. (Leon takes Fuzee's arm, and is dragging him towards Ninette and Rosine, when they pass to L.H., Ninette turns her head and looks at Leon.)

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (to Rosine)What a handsome young man!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: She is looking at me, Fuzee. I'll be shot but she's looking at me! She turned her head.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Nonsense!—it's your head that's turned.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: How he does look at me!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What will they think of us? Go—go in.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: It's your father's we are going to—so we must pass them again. (Ninette and Rosine cross again towards Berguins's house—Fuzee and Leon cross to L.H.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll follow them.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (detaining him)Halt!

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (stops at door)What a beautiful day!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Go in—do! (pushes her in, and slams the door in Leon's face as he is about to follow.)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (L.H.)There's a repulse for you! I hope you'll not return to the charge.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (R.A.)I'll not stir a step, from this spot, till they come out again.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Nonsense! It's a guard will soon weary you. Come, there's a time for all things—for love, war, dancing, singing, eating, and drinking—and for the two latter, my inward monitor tells me it is now the present time.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But where's our money?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Aye—another of your mad tricks—your passion for dancing, last night, brought us into a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, hadn't we the best of it?—didn't we put them all to the rout, bag and baggage?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Took away all the women—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Thrash'd all the men—

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Almost killed the Burgomaster's nephew—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And lost all our money in the action.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Exactly so. Then we returned with difficulty to our quarters—groped about for our haversacks in the dark—started upon a forced march without a single ration, not a sous in our pockets— the Gendarmes at our heels—and you stopping to wink your eye at a girl.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But such a girl!—a delicious creature!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: A cold fowl would be a much more delicious creature to me at this moment.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (crosses to L.)You think of nothing but eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: And you think of nothing but the wenches.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I've such a susceptible heart.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: And I've such an empty stomach.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There's no pleasure without love.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: There's no pleasure without drinking.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: 'Tis love inspires the soldier!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: And wine!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And they are the only things which constitute happiness.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: There I agree with you. Now, left face—march!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Halt! I shall stay here.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: But without money?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You forget my lottery-ticket.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Your lottery-ticket! I wish we had the six francs it cost.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My numbers are 11, 28, and 40; and I think they'll win.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Ha! (sees the numbers on the board at the lottery office, crosses at back, and instantly covers them with his hat) Leon!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Will you wager double rations, payable when I can shew that you have lost?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Uncover—take away your hat.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Your numbers are?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Well, now for it; look. (shewing one)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Capital! I'm sure you'll win (laughing)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now, for another. (Fuzee shews another number) 11, there's one at all events. What's the next? (Fuzee uncovers) Ah! there's 28, and there's 40—huzza! Victory, victory! I'll get my ticket, and claim the cash. (undoing his haversack)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: What a glorious supper we'll have! Lucky dogs we are!(sings) “For love and wine, to fall in fight, becomes—”

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: This is not my haversack.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh, ruin, despair, and death! repeat it not—say it not again, lest I run distracted in your sight.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Fuzee!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Leon!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We're ruined! We took our haversacks in the dark—you recollect.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And I have taken the wrong one.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Good-bye to the supper.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There was a soldier slept in our room last night. In the darkness I must have taken his haversack for mine.Fuzee crosses to R.H., taking up haversack—Leon goes up to door at back, R.H.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh, fool! fool! Devil take the haversack! (throws it on the stage, L.H., third or fourth wing) Oh, my suffering internals!— my disappointed cravings! how shall I satisfy you? Ninette and Rosine appear at Berguins's door. —Leon, where the deuce are you? (he passes to L.H., and turning, sees Leon R.H.) Zounds! there he is again. The fellow's out of his senses, and I shall lose mine! I must comfort myself with my pipe. (sits on the ground, L.H., takes out his German pipe, lights it, and smokes, as Ninette and Rosine pass down the stage—Leon bows)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (R., to Ninette)Turn your head, dear. Rosine tries to hinder her.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (R.)I wouldn't be so rude.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'm ashamed of you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (accosting them)Pardon the liberty I take, dear Miss, but I cannot resist the lively impression which you have made upon this susceptible heart.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (L., smoking)Silly boy, silly boy!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (to Ninette)Come, come.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Hush! the gentleman spoke to us—it will be rude not to answer him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I have loved you but five minutes, but I feel it will be for life.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: If you listen to him, good-bye to Cousin Cocklet.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do not forbid me to hope.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir, you are not acquainted with us.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: He'll soon be acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I arrived but this instant: I beheld you, and my heart's no longer my own.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Just arrived? Ah, Ninette! if it should be your brother?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Ah! if it should? But yet I hope not.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I should be so glad.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: May I not be permitted to know the subject of your whisperings?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir—(to Ninette)—but shall I ask him?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What may have brought you to this village?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Brought me? These. (slapping his thigh)

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: But for what purpose?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nothing! 'Twas my good fortune brought me here, since I have met with you;—and, if you smile upon me, I shall be the happiest of the happy.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: It's not my brother—so much the better!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: It's not your brother—so much the worse!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (singing)“Faithful remembrance of my Mary dear.”

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (to Rosine)What's the name of your lovely friend?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: My name is Hannibal Fuzee. (smoking)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Who spoke to you?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: You spoke in such a sweet voice I thought it was one of the ladies asking you the name of your lovely friend.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Come, Ninette, we promised to call on Madame Chalon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Permit me to follow you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: You would'nt be so rude, I hope.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Indeed, you must not—we are going to return this way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But your name, my divinity?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Can be of no consequence to you.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Certainly not; of what possible consequence can it be to you, that my name is Ninette.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Ninette? What as plendid name! Never shall I forget it while I have life. Promise me you'll soon return.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: We can promise nothing.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: To be sure not; but we shall return sometime or other.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Farewell, dear, dear Ninette! (seizes her hand to kiss it)

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (comes between them, and prevents it)Are you mad, child?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: You might have let him kiss my hand.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'm ashamed of you.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I ain't.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Nonsense. (crosses to R.H.) Come along.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: You might have let him kiss my hand—there could have been no harm in that.Rosine hurries Ninette off R.H.—Ninette places her hand behind her; Leon kisses it.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: I'll put you all in the guard-house. Caterwauling in the public streets! Have you no delicacy?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'm the happiest man in the world! I'm sure she loves me! I'll never leave her!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: So you've said and sworn to many a regiment of petticoat infantry. (rising) But your haversack—you'll endeavour to find that, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We'll see to that presently. I'm engaged now,

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Ten thousand bombs and cannonades! have you anything that ought more to engage you? You were on a forced march, you said, to Merival, to find your father, whom you never saw; and without the certificate which your nurse gave you, and which was in the pocket-book in your haversack, how will you be able to reconnoitre?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We shall see.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: And your lottery ticket?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Dear Ninette!—what a prize I should gain, could I win your little heart!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh, the devil! Instead of thinking how he shall find his father, he's thinking how he shall make a father of himself.Enter Margot, from inn, R.; she stops on perceiving Leon, and examines him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, Fuzee, if you don't wish to remain here, you are your own master, and can pursue your route.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: No, you are not comfortably billeted, and I sha'n't leave you. Go your length—march where you please. Perhaps I may find a pretty girl to amuse me; and then we'll stay here for life. Though I may be the last in the field, I'm the last to leave it.(sings)“My arm it is my country's right.”—How that old woman is looking at me!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot be deceived! (comes down R.H. and looks at Leon) 'Tis he!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: The mine is blown up, Leon! We are pursued—let us beat a retreat!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What are you talking about, my good woman?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: She says she knows us. The gendarmes are in pursuit of us, you know, for thrashing the man at the dance. She may be one of the witnesses. Let us decamp!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Sir—will you be so kind as to tell me what regiment you belong to?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside to Leon)That's a bait,—change the name of the corps.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I serve in the—in the—

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: In the 20th regiment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Eh?—in the 20th regiment—and your name is Victor? (joyfully)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Precisely—Victor. That's his name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I knew I was right,—it is our young master. How happy your father will be to see you!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: His father!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you knew how delighted he was with your letter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My letter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, bless your eyes, nose, and mouth!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Zounds!—here's an old woman struck with him now— none of 'em notice me.

sp.speaker: Leon:
sp.p: My good woman, you are—?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Hush!—let her go on. If she's troublesome, I'll take her off your hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Don't you think I know you? I, that rear'd you from a baby.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My good lady—

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Hush! I've taken a fancy to the dear creature myself. My little love, what is my comrade's father's name and business. Eh? (crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: His name is Gavard, a tavern-keeper, a dealer in wine and spirits.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: True, true, Victor, it is your father—it must be your father. Dealer in wine and spirits! It mnst be your father.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, no, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (stops his mouth)A tavern-keeper; it's your father. Go, my good woman—tell the old gentleman, his son has arrived, with an intimate friend; tell him the son loves the women, and his intimate friend doats upon wine and spirits;—tell him, to place a dozen of his oldest and best wine upon table. Right-about face! March!

sp.speaker: Mars
sp.p: How delighted my master will be! Oh, bless your dear eyes! I knew you the moment I saw you! Exit into inn.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How could you be so mad as to tell the old woman I was her master's son?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: How can you be so mad as to wish to deny it? If they will father you—Zounds! Leon, you are looking for a father, ain't you? I've found one for you—a tavern-keeper—yon can't have a better father. Nonsense! be this Victor for once: if you won't, I'll be his son—he shall be father to one of us.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We shall be discovered to be impostors.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Well, they can but kick us out again: perhaps we shall have astonished a good dinner by that time. A dinner! Oh, zounds! you shall be his son. The nurse is convinced you are his son, and fathers are the last people to know exactly, who their sons are.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But it can't last.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: But we must make it last till after dinner.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Suppose he should offer me money?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Accept it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Suppose he should prepare a repast?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Eat it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: He might offer me his house.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Take it. Here comes the nurse and your father—don't flinch. Stop; you slip on one side while I prepare the place for you. Be guided by me, and conceal yourself a moment.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll see if I can't catch a glimpse of the girls again.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Deuce take the girls!—think of your father. Go, Go! (pushes him off, L.H.U.E.)

div.stage: Enter Gavard and Margot from Inn, R.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Where is he? Where is he?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (L.)Who are you seeking, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (C.)I'm seeking for my son—my dear son.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh!—you are, Mr.—Mr. Gavard, dealer in wine and spirits! You are the father of my friend, and the master of the Rising Sun?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: But where's my son? Why did'nt he come instantly to his father?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: He did'nt know the house.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: That's impossible! He was sixteen when he left us, and though I've had the front newly painted, still he must remember the spot

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: True, but—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Ah! (sighing) I did not wish to break the unfortunate intelligence—you will perceive it, alas, too soon.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What has happened to my son?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (R.)Good gracious! What has happened to the boy?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Since the last time he was on the sick list—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: On the sick list?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: His head—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Since his severe fit, his brains are not exactly—you know what I mean—?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Fortunately he's only very dangerous at intervals: but for his memory—gone, Sir—quite gone!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: But the letter which he wrote to me—

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: I dictated that.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: That was sensible enough.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Of course. I had gathered the secret of your being his father from his lucid intervals—and—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: But where is he now?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: He had a fit not five minutes since; so I seated him by himself, on a post in the next street, for a little repose. It's my method of treating him.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Are you sure he's my son?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: As for that, I really cannot answer.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: He is called Victor Gavard.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: His name I'll answer for.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: 'Tis he; poor fellow! Tell me, friend, has he always conducted himself well?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Like a hero!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: And has he received any recompense?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh! my dear friend, if the nation was obliged to reward every brave action, one year's war would ruin the Treasury.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (taking up the haversack which had been thrown by Fuzee back to R.H.)Bless me! this is his haversack—is it not?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Yes, yes, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Stop, stop. (searching it) Here's his pocket-book. Margot, take my boy's haversack into the house. She goes in with it. —I'll see if his papers are correct.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside)The devil! Blown to atoms! I'm returned killed! (to Gavard) My dear friend, you must not look at his papers. (tries to take the pocket-book from him)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Not look at my son's papers?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: There may be letters in it, from some of his ladies—and ladies of distinction, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Nonsense, nonsense,—I don't care for all that. I used to have ladies of distinction love me when I was a young man. It's in the family. (takes out papers)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (trying to get them)But—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Be quiet. I will examine them. (examines them)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside)Devil take the haversack! We're ruined!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside, and seeing Gavard agitated)The old man's getting angry—I'd better run for it.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Sir! (turns hastily to Fuzee, who, thinking Gavard is about to strike him, places his hand on his sword)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Slowly—slowly.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What do you mean, my dear friend? You are a strange fellow. It is indeed my son,—these are his papers, and here is the letter I sent him.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (astonished) Indeed!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: How shall I repay the obligation for the care you have taken of him.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: My dear Sir, my feelings of friendship for your son as a comrade, as a soldier, are beyond any recompense, excepting a decent dinner, or something of that sort. (aside) Devil take me if I understand all this.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: But do you think his malady incurable?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Oh dear, no; good wine, good fish, and good fowl will do him some good.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: He shall live like a Prince. Margot!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! I think we are right enough now.Enter Margot from inn, R.—Leon at the same time from L.H.U.E.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Here he is.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's the dear boy!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: 'Tis he! My dear boy! (embraces Leon, R.H.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My dear young master! (embraces Leon, L.H.)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: My dear comrade! (embraces them all together—Margot passes at back to R.H.)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (to Gavard)My dear Sir, you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside to Leon)Don't be a fool.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: He does not remember me. Dear, dear!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Arn't you ashamed of yourself? Listen to the voice of Nature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis your fond father.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Don't you recollect my features?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How the devil should I? I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Are you mad? Oh, the devil! (crosses to L.H.)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What a misfortune!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor boy! Good gracious!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Don't be unhappy, it will soon pass over. (aside to Leon) Why don't you rush into his arms?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (aside to Fuzee)I sha'n't stir from this spot. The girls promised to return, and I'm stationary.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: You are—both post and foolscap.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (to Fuzee)What does he say?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: He asked for something to drink.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Run, Margot!—lay the cloth, and provide everything of the best—the best in the house.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Make haste, my good woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Everything shall be ready in an instant. Poor boy!—what a misfortune? Exit into Inn.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (aside)I wish that dear little Ninette would return.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: He says he begins to remember you. (Fuzee gets back)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Does he? Victor—Victor, my boy!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Don't bother! I'm nobody's boy!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside to Leon, L.H.)I'll shoot you—by the lord, I'll shoot you! (to Gavard) We shall do very well, my good friend; and when we have sat down to table, (crosses to C.) you'll then see how much better he'll be. (aside to Leon) Come—come! Zounds! I'm starved!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (aside to Fuzee) I tell you, I won't stir till I have seen the girls again. I'll not deceive anybody.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (aside)I wish there was not a woman in the world!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Come, my son—come.Enter Margot, from inn.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: All's ready.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Come, comrade, come—dinner's on table.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I won't stir!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The soup will get cold.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I won't stir!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Come, come, my dear boy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I won't stir!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Recollect your round-text copy at school—“Obey your parents.”

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There she is—there she is! My dear Ninette! how happy I am to see you again! (crosses to her)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: He remembers his sister, at all events.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (L.H. of Gavard)He called her by her name.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (to Leon)Don't, don't!—my father's here.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Don't you know who it is, Ninette? It is your brother.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (R.)My intended, I declare!

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (R.C.)My brother! What a pity!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Her brother? I'm so happy!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (L., crosses to C.)Embrace your sister.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: What a pity he's my brother!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: If he were as handsome as an Adonis, I wouldn't have him, if he didn't love me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (L.C.)But the dinner's getting cold.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Sensible soul! she's right.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (C.)Come, my son.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Embrace me, my dear Ninette, and I shall indeed be happy! (crosses to her)

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (flounces up the stage)Mar and Gav.He's quite deranged!

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Quite!Leon leads Ninette into inn, followed by Rosine, Gavard, and Margot.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Victory! victory! If this mistake is not discovered in less than an hour, I'll provender myself for three days to come. Right-about face!—quick march! Exit into inn.Enter Berguin, the Burgomaster, from the house, R.H.U.E.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Where can my nephew Cocklet be? His absence quite alarms me. He asked permission to go to a dance, but it is now time he had returned. I hope nothing has happened to the poor lad. But I shouldn't be surprised if there had;—for this last month everything has gone wrong; our prison, too, is in such a dilapidated state, that if we had any one to arrest, they would easily escape.— Eh? here comes my nephew. Why, Cocklet!Enter Cocklet R.H., his face patched and scarred.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Oh! uncle, here's a condition I'm in!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What's the matter? Been getting into trouble, eh?

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I'm black and blue from head to foot;—I'm a human rainbow!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What have you been about?

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I went to the dance, you know, and there we were as merry as grigs, and the fiddles a-going like anything, and I dancing like an angel, when in came two fiery dragons—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Dragoons, Cocklet.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Well, then, dragoons. And one of them, without any questions, or at all behaving like a gentleman, stepped up to my partner, and dos'd-a-dos'd away with her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That was very rude!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: But I wasn't at all daunted—oh no! I walked up to him, took off my hat, and to alarm him, I said, “Sir, what do you mean by that, Sir?—do you know who you have offended?” “I have not the pleasure,” said he. “Then,” said I, “know, Sir, that I'm my uncle's nevy.” “Then there's my love to you, and my compliments to your uncle;” and he hit me a plaguy hard slap on the side of my face.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Ay, but it wasn't well. That put me in a passion, and I gave him a kick;—and then the riot began. He tossed me about, as one would have tossed an orange—the lads came to my assistance, and a pitched battle commenced; then the other soldier set upon us —knocked us all down, one after the other—kissed and touzled all the women, young and old—and then scampered off, leaving me in this condition.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Run to the gendarmes, and give them an account of the affair, while I step into neighbour Gavard's. I thought something had happened to you, from what I heard Ninette say. I'll trounce the scoundrels, for daring to insult the nephew of a Burgomaster! Exit into inn.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Some of the lads have told the gendarmes, and I hope by this time they are in custody. What shall I do?Enter Victor, from the back, L.H.U.E., with his haversack on his shoulder.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I've been so long absent, that in returning to my native village, I scarcely recognise a soul. Attention, my friend! (slaps Cocklet on the back, down L.H.)

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Ah! this is one of them. Uncle—uncle! He won't arrest any one, for fear of getting into trouble. I'll run for the genarmes. Exit R.H.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: What's the matter with the lad? He seems scared at my appearance.—I'm impatient to embrace my poor father, and my little Rosine, the Burgomaster's daughter, and my intended wife. (sees sign) “The Rising Sun!” Ah! 'tis my father's, sure enough. (is entering the inn, when Rosine appears)

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (staring at Victor)Dear me!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: This cannot be my sister.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How much he resembles the dragoon in-doors! Exactly like my intended. (aloud) Who do you want, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Mr. Gavard, my pretty lass. Are you his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No, but I soon shall be.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Soon!—how?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: His son is to be my future husband.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: His son?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: We have been betrothed to each other from childhood.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (aside)'Tis she!—'tis Rosine! (aloud) And you do not object to marry Gavard's son?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I shall not, if he will have me, because he's a very nice young man.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: From being in his company.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: But you cannot remember him sufficiently

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Bless your heart! remember him? It's not quite so long since I saw him that I should forget him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Ten years, at least.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Ten minutes, you mean.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: He's arrived; I've seen him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: She knows me, then, after ten years' absence. This is indeed astonishing. Dear Rosine! (taking her hand)

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I declare he knows my name.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How happy am I to see you once again. Do not think me bold in thus addressing you; on the terms on which we are, it cannot be called a liberty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What terms, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I love you, dear Rosine—I was convinced I should, from the moment I saw you—and if you love me with equal fervour, nothing shall retard our happiness.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Upon my word, you have arranged it all very nicely.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Rosine, do not seek to hide your love for me, and your joy at my return.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I'm not asleep and dreaming. (aside) I like him better, much better, than Victor Gavard. I wish I could break off my match with him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Tomorrow, shall unite us in those bonds, which will assure for ever our felicity,

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But my father?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: He will rejoice in our happiness, and give us his blessing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'm engaged, Sir, to the son of Mr. Gavard here.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I know you are, dear Rosine—you don't appear to comprehend me—I am—Enter Gavard, from inn.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (C.)The devil! A Soldier talking to Rosine!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The soldier was enquiring for you, Mr. Gavard. (aside) What a nice young man!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (gazes at Victor)For me? (to Rosine) Rosine, go into the house, your father is asking for you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Directly.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Yes, yes, go.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What a pity! I should like to have staid. What a charming young soldier! Exit into Inn

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (aside)He does not know me!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: You'll excuse me, Sir, but I can't help looking at you—you are so like my son.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My father! (rushing to him)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Embrace your son!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Stop, stop, one moment, if you please.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Do you fear to press me to your heart, before you know, whether I am worthy of you?—But, you may own me without a blush; I have done my duty in the field, and glory is my reward.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what is that to me?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: I have listened very patiently to you, and now it is my turn to speak. Don't think to dupe me. Go—go! Be satisfied that you have failed in your attempt, and depart without incurring worse consequences. You arrived too late.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Too late?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: This swindling is unworthy the coat you wear.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Go, Sir—you can't dupe me!Exit into inn, banging the door in Victor's face.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Can it be possible? After ten years' absence, to return to my native country—to my father—and find his heart and door closed against me!Enter Cocklet, Gendarmes, and Brigadier Louis, R.H.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Hush!—there he is! Not yet! (they retire to back, R.H.)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Some one must have calumniated me. In his letter, he testified the most lively impatience for my return. I'll have an explanation. (knocks at door)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (opening door)What! have you not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Will you listen to me?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Will you go along about your business, and not come here to disturb our happiness?

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: (comes forward)Oh! he has been disturbing you, has he? Uncle, come out,—here are the Gendarmes.Berguin enters from the inn—Brigadier Louis and Gendarmes advance L.H.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (R.H.) Be cautious, nephew;—you are sure he is the person? I never like arresting people myself, for fear of mistakes and getting into trouble.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: (R.C.)It's no mistake. I'd take six oaths it is the same man that took away my partner and sent you his compliments.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Brigadier Louis, arrest that man.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: (L.)In the name of the law, you are my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (L.C.)I! For what? (Gendarmes place themselves on each side of Victor)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (C.)So, my honest fellow, you have got yourself into the hands of the Justice.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I have a great mind to let him go again, for fear of making a mistake. Are you sure, he's the man? (to Cocklet)

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Certain.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You have seen (crosses past Cocklet) this young gentleman—my nephew, Coco Cocklet, before?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I think so—I saw—that is, for an instant.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: You hear how he stammers—see what a condition you have made my frontispiece in—but, now I shall have revenge.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I never touched you—that is—I but gave you a friendly tap on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Very likely indeed; as if one had a shoulder in the middle of one's face.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It's quite clear. Away with him!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I tell you, you are all mistaken.Enter Rosine, R.H.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What's the matter, father?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Putting a scoundrel under arrest.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: A scoundrel! Oh, dear, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Render up your arms, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My arms! (draws his sword angrily, they all recoil) Were I not conscious of my innocence, this should purchase my liberty; but, I am tranquil, and surrender myself and my sword. Now, let me know of what I am accus'd.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You are accused of committing a riot at a dance, of kissing all the women, old and young, married and single, of putting to rout all the old men; and with open violence and malice aforethought, beating all the young men, particularly that handsome young man, Coco Cocklet, my nephew.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: It's a falsehood! (to Gavard) And you, my father—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Father! What does he mean by father? (crosses to Gav.)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: No, no—he's an impostor. My son has arrived—I introduced him to you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You had better confront them, for fear of a mistake.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: No, no;—my son is in such a state, the slightest agitation might be fatal to him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (to Gendarmes)Let us examine the papers in his haversack. (crosses up to Victor)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Do, Sir—do. (takes off haversack and gives it to Berguin) You will then see the proofs of my innocence—(to Gavard) the proofs of my being your son, if the strongest proofs are not already in your heart.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (who has taken the haversack and examined the pocket-book)What do you say you are called?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Victor Gavard.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That's false!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: False?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You are here called Leon Sabertash, an orphan.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Leon Sabertash?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Tis true, young man; and without any fear of making a mistake or getting into trouble, I have no hesitation in pronouncing you to be a swindler.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A swindler—a swindler!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: A rascal—a footpad!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: There is some mistake.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Do you dispute this? (shewing passport)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: That is not my passport.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Then how came it in your pocket-book?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Let me look. It's not my pocket-book!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Oh! he'll next swear it is not his haversack.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: And that, Sir, is not my haversack.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: There—there! Didn't I prophesy he'd say so?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Then how did you come by it?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I cannot say—I am bewildered!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Let us examine his papers. (opens a packet) Letters from his different mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (aside)Oh dear, oh dear!—what a naughty young man!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Sir, allow me to say, I know nothing—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Letter from a negress.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—from a black woman!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Those papers do not belong to me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: As I'm Burgomaster, here's a lottery ticket!—and I declare, the ticket that has gained the great prize! The numbers are, 11, 28, and 40.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: He stole them, depend upon it!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You won't deny that the haversack belongs to you now?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And you refuse this? (shewing ticket)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Certainly,—it is not mine. And learn, Sir, to the heart of a soldier, gold is as dust, when balanced by his honour!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (aside)He's a noble young man, after all!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Oh! that's only his fine way of flumgummering people.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Remove the prisoner an instant.The Gendarmes march Victor to the back of the Stage. Rosine and Cocklet retire up.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This dragoon astonishes me! His refusing to own the haversack, when the fortunate ticket was discovered, astounds my magisterial faculties! What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: He must go to prison till the truth is discovered.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But our prison is in such a dilapidated state.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: I'll get you out of that difficulty,—I'll lend you a room in the old building, which I'm going to pull down at the back of my garden,—the windows are grated.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Rosine! (she comes down R.H., Cocklet L.H.) Don't whisper a syllable to a soul! Go and get the key of the old room; it is to serve as a prison for the soldier.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Indeed! (aside) That's delightful!

p.stage: (goes to Cocklet, who is in L.H. corner)

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: It is on the bunch which hangs in the bedroom; and take care that my son knows nothing of what passes—it might disturb his mind.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Not a word!

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Make haste, that's a good child!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I'll be cautious. Exit into inn.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: (to Louis)Brigadier Louis, let your men take the prisoner by the back of my house, so that my son may not see them.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In the name of the law, conduct the culprit to prison.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My father, I hope you will soon see your error.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: March! (crosses to R.H., heading Gendarmes)

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: That's right—lock him up!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Father, you will regret this!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Away with him! It's no mistake! Away with him!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Away with him—away with him!

div.stage: The Gendarmes file by, two and two, with Victor in the centre, Berguin, Gavard, and Cocklet, in great glee, following, and exeunt R.H.U.E.
SCENE I — A Room, with Antique Furniture—At back, an Alcove, with Grated Window, and Curtain—A small Door, L.H 3 E.—Stage dark—A Cabinet, L.H. near U.E.—Victor discovered pacing the room.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Fate, love, and nature, all conspire against me! I thought to prove their error, when the very papers, which I relied upon, turned evidence against me—stampt me as a rogue and an imposter! My knapsack has been changed, but when or how, I'm at a loss to guess. I should know this chamber—it is my father's—and 'twas here I play'd in childhood, with Rosine—she, whom I expected to clasp in my arms, as my wife, and receive my father's blessing—and he disowns me, and drives me from his door!—the more I meditate, the more perplex'd I am. Some one comes. (the large door L.H. is unlocked, and Louis enters)

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: The Burgomaster has signified his intention of visiting you.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: So much the better? He intends treating you with the utmost severity.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: If he is just, he will not.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: He is here.Enter Berguin, L.H.D.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: (to Victor)Well, Sir, have you made up your mind, to confess the truth?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I am not in the habit, Sir, of speaking aught but truth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Still obstinate! Brigadier Louis, retire—leave me alone with the villain. I'll worm the truth out of him. I'm convinced there's no mistake, because, I'm always so cautious, before I proceed to extremities.Exit Louis L.H.D., Berguin watches him, closes the door, then runs to Victor, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My dear boy, make yourself happy!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Dear boy! What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hush! The gendarmes are at the door,—I must conceal from them the excess of my joy; so do not speak loud, but listen. I have found the proofs of your birth.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Endeavour to contain yourself.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How have you discovered them?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In unfolding your papers.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My papers! Where are they?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: In your haversack.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Who has my haversack?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The Brigadier.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Has he? Oh, my father!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hush!—don't name me just yet.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Name you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Here is the certificate. (shews paper)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: What certificate?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Of farmer Jacquard, and your nurse at Merival. But I can't explain myself more clearly till you are released from this place. Don't be unhappy, my dear boy; the Brigadier will soon settle everything, when I have had a little conversation with him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: But explain to me—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hush! not now. I must first endeavour to get you out of trouble, without any partiality being observed on my part. Don't be alarmed about your haversack—that and your papers are quite safe.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hush! not a word more, my dear boy. How proud I shall be to acknowledge you. (embraces him and exit, L.H.—the door is heard to lock)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: What can all this mean? What have I to do with a nurse and a farmer at Merival, and a certificate? Zounds! I can comprehend nothing. Eh! there's another key turning. Now, 'tis the little door at the back.Rosine appears at the little door in the alcove, and comes forward.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hush! save yourself—you can go out by this little door.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Why should I go?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: They will punish you for beating Cocklet and endeavouring to impose upon Gavard. I have obtained the key of the little door here—it opens upon a flight of steps that lead to the garden. The night is coming on—there will be no moon, and you will easily escape unperceived: though in escaping, and leaving this place, you will have less to complain of than I.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Escape! I abandon you, Rosine? No! you are mine, and I shall never leave yon.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now, don't attempt to deceive me. I have taken an interest in your welfare, and would do you a kindness, and I must say, it is a great pity, so nice a young man, as you appear to be, should be such a shocking fellow.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How can you do me the injustice?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Remember, the letters from your mistresses.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: You are deceived, Rosine.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: That I might have forgiven, but for you to have such a strange taste as to encourage a woman of color! that I can't look over.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: It was not my haversack. Rosine; and I assure you, I am Victor Gavard.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now, you make me feel quite uncomfortable, to hear you tell such palpable stories. Victor Gavard has arrived, and is now in the house with a comrade, who is singing him to sleep with a half dozen of empty bottles of wine before him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: It is some impostor, who has taken my name, but he shall confront me, and in my presence, he will not dare to persist in his deceit. Then, my dear Rosine, I trust you will not find me unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Ah! could I but dare to hope.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Do you then love me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Alas! I am afraid my fears, my hopes, and anxieties, upon your account, spring from a stronger feeling, than a little interest in your welfare.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Dear, dear, Rosine, you restore me to new life, and, when I have confronted the villain, who would have supplanted me—

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hush!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: What! why are you alarmed?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: There's some one coming; I have left the key in the door, and I would'nt be discovered here for the world. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Here, here, this cabinet—step in—quick, quick! (Victor opens the door of the cabinet, places Rosine inside it, and leans against the door)

div.stage: Enter Leon, from the little door, with his hat in his hand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: That dear little Ninette, has consented to meet me here, to give me a private interview, because she thinks I am her brother. Bless her little eyes? I would'nt be her brother, to be made the fattest major in the army! If I must be related to her, I trust it will be, in the capacity of a tender husband. So I'll undeceive her, throw myself at her feet, and take possession of the garrison—her heart. But, how is this? She told me to wait on the steps, leading to the door, while she went for the key of it, and I found it already open! Hollo! What's that? The figure of a man! Who goes there? (Victor comes down, Leon throws down his hat, and draws his sabre)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Answer for yourself—who are you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Answer me—who are you?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Answer me—whom do you seek?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Answer me, Sir—what are you doing here?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I shall not answer you,—you are armed, and I am not.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Armed?—there! (throws down his sabre) Now we are equal. I do not wish for any advantage.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (peeping from the door of the cabinet)What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Some one comes! Take your sword. (he takes the sword Leon has relinquished)Enter Brigadier Louis, followed by a Gendarme, L.H.D.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: What do you say? What do you do here? What have you brought the prisoner to aid him in his escape? (to Gendarme) Why did you allow the dragoon to visit his comrade?

sp.speaker: Gend.
sp.p: I, Brigadier?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: You are always doing more than you are commanded. You deserve reporting and punishing.

sp.speaker: Gend.
sp.p: But, Brigadier—

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: I won't listen to any excuses. No one shall see the prisoner without my permission. (takes up Leon's hat and puts it on Victor's head) Now, Sir, take your hat, and go about your business.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Sir, you—

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: How dare you attempt to speak, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But that hat is—

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Silence! (to Victor) Go, Sir—go about your business!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: But, Sir, allow me to justify myself—

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Out with him—out with him!

sp.speaker: Gend.
sp.p: You must go out. (forcing Victor to L.H.D.)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I've no objection to go out, but—

sp.speaker: Gend.
sp.p: Go, Sir! (thrusting him out and shutting door)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (aside)He's got my hat and sabre!

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: (to Gendarme)You remain on the outside, and be more cautious in future. No words,—do as I command yon. Exit Gendarme L.H.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (from the cabinet)What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: (to Leon)You must excuse our apparent severity, but for the present it is necessary. The Burgomaster is arranging the business for you, and will soon be here.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: He will settle the affair for you as soon as possible—though you certainly treated his nephew very ill.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh! they know it was me, then?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Of course, or we should not have placed you under arrest.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Arrest!—when?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: A short time since. What unnecessary questions you ask!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Am I under arrest?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: You know that.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (aside)What the deuce does he mean?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Now, don't seek any longer to disguise the truth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You have asked me nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Your name is Leon Sabertash.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: That's true enough.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: The Burgomaster has told me all; and, as a proof, I come on his part. He has confided this pocket-book to me, with your lottery ticket, and the certificate of your birth. You know it, don't you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes! that is the certificate of Farmer Jacquard and my old nurse. She told me to take every care of it. I'm rejoiced you have found it, and my lottery ticket. Huzza! I shall be a rich man at last, and marry my dear Ninette.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Well, there may be no objection to that.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Won't there? Why, what a fine old fellow you are—I like you amazingly. But, my haversack, tell me?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Is perfectly safe. Oh, if you had but seen the tears flowing down the smooth cheeks of the Burgomaster when he mentioned you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: But don't you be afflicted.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I don't intend.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: They were tears of joy. But he requests you not to say who you are till your discharge is signed. So be cautious not to mention your father's name.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Not much fear of that, as I never heard it.

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Because the affair would become public, and he doesn't wish the world to accuse him of favouring you, against the course of justice. Farewell; in two hours, at latest, I hope you'll be free.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Zounds! I've come to prison of my own accord But why does the Burgomaster, whom I never saw, take such an interest in me?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: The interest of a father for his son to be sure.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A father?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p: Yes! the Burgomaster is your father.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Who told you so?

sp.speaker: Louis.
sp.p:
I cannot remain here any longer. Calm your anxiety, as all will yet be well. But stop—you shall not be in the dark, I will leave you a light. Robert, a light!
Enter Gendarme with a lantern which Louis gives to Leon. —There, make yourself comfortable; for the present, farewell. Exit L.H.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, this is strange! (places lantern on table, R.H.) Everybody is determined to be my father to-day. I've been wanting a father all my life, and now they come as quick as misfortunes. I must choose the best of them: though I should be sorry to give up the innkeeper. He makes a capital father—keeps such a glorious table, and such splendid wine! Rosine is trying to escape—Leon turns and sees her. —Hallo! hallo! who is that?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (hiding her face in her hands)I am lost!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (L.H.)A woman!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, don't betray me!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What! my reserved Rosine—the rigid fair one who snatched the white hand of Ninette from my lips, and disappointed me of the sweetest morsel that has been placed before me to-day? Oh, fie, fie, Miss Fickle!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: On my knees I beg—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, no, don't go on your knees—don't reverse the order of Nature which makes it the peculiar privilege of our sex. If anybody is to go on their knees, it shall be myself. (kneels) Now then, dear Rosine, I implore you whenever you may again see me attempt to kiss the hand of Ninette, don't snatch it away so spitefully—pray don't; on my knees I beseech you to be kind to me.Enter Ninette at door at back.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Very pretty, indeed!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Here is the lady.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Ninette! (turns and advances to Ninette)

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (R.H.)Oh, don't come near me! I didn't think you were so sly, Rosine. What! caught yon in the fact, did I? This was the reason I couldn't find the key of the little door anywhere: I might have hunted for it till doomsday. Don't attempt to speak to me. (crosses past Rosine) I'll tell your father—upon my life I'll tell your father.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Don't cry, dear Ninette.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: That's silly of you, child, as he is your brother you know; and even if he did love me, it could'nt be of any consequence to you.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: For all that, it's not pleasant to be an eye witness of such goings on.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now, hear me, Ninette, and you, Rosine. (crosses to centre) I assure you, ladies, I am not Gavard's son, nor am I, Ninette's brother.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Then that makes it the more unpleasant. Who in het name of patience, are you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Upon my life, I don't know—Indeed I don't. I belong to anybody that will own me.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Oh, dear?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Somebody's coming!

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: If it should be my father?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: If it should be mine?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll put out the light. (blows out the candle, Stage dark) Conceal yourselves. (Ninette runs into the cabinet, and closes the door. Rosine tries to follow her, but finding Ninette there first, runs into the alcove, and conceals herself behind the curtain of the grated window. Leon gets into corner R.H.U.E.)Enter Victor at the back door.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: It's very fortunate, I found the little back door open. I must release Rosine, before I demand to see the villain, who has taken my name. I thought I heard voices disputing, as I ascended the steps.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.l: “Gaily for love and wine to fight,

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Who the deuce is that? I must step aside. (he retreats into the alcove)

div.stage: Enter Fuzee, by the little door, with bottles of wine under his arms and in his hands.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Huzza! glorious dinner!—cut down whole ranks of poultry and charged a flank of beef like a hero—undermined the fortification of a giblet pie—ransacked the citadel of a venison pasty—attacked a fine regiment of black bottles that followed up in the rear—knocked their heads off in double quick time, and took the gentlemen prisoners. Nothing like victualling the garrison, in case of a siege and blockade. And if we should be obliged to decamp, without sound of trumpet, we sha'n't retreat empty handed. I'll hide some of the spoils of war here. I've a cold fowl and a bit of venison pasty in my handkerchief, and these prisoners of war must keep them company. (puts them down in R.H. corner) Oh, you rascals! you thought to mount into the ramparts of my head by escalade, did you? Pretty regiment you are! Sweet uniform! Black, with white facings, and scarlet hats. Nothing so handsome in the service!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: While they were signing the discharge for the dragoon, I'm certain I saw Miss Ninette slip up this way: if I catch a glimpse of her I'll watch what she's about. (gets down L.H., between door and cupboard)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: What's that? a spy in the camp? If he comes near our provisions I'll blow his brains out!

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I wish I could slip out.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: A soldier here? Perhaps the villain that has caused all this mischief.

div.stage: Rosine comes from her hiding-place, and is about to go out at the door as Margot appears—She slips back to her place.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I'll keep watch here, I'm determined. I know there's some connoodling going on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (entering)It's quite dark here. I've missed five or six bottles of wine, and I'm almost sure that varlet, Cocklet, has stolen them, and has come here to put them out of the way. I'll watch him. I saw him coming to this room.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Here's a regiment of bush-fighters pouring into quarters. I must lay close here.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (comes from alcove)I'll get Rosine out of the cabinet, at all events.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: (opening the door of the cabinet)Hush!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Come, love, come.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: That's her voice—she's got company here. I'm quite shocked!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hear whispering—there's some intrigue going on—that villain, Cocklet, has brought some of his sluts here.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I'll venture now. Come this way.Leon. and Vic.Which way?Ninette gets to back, C.—Leon, L.H.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: (coming forward)Ninette, are you out?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Yes—this way.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I've a great mind to call out.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: What a coufounded hushing and buzzing there is!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Where are you? Margot comes down R.H. of Victor—Ninette R.H. of Margot.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: You'd better not come near me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's mistaken. Leon passes down to Cocklet, and takes his hand.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I'm taken!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Now, dear Rosine, let us away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Rosine? The booby Cocklet!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Dear Ninette!

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: I shall faint away!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Where have you got to? (gets near Fuzee, who seizes her)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Here I am, my dear creature.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh! it's the wrong man! (screams, and tries to escape from Fuzee)

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Hollo! who goes there?

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: Murder! Murder!

div.stage: Enter Berguin and Gavard, with lights, L.H.—Cocklet falls on his knees with fright—Rosine flies to R.H. of Cocklet—Victor, seeing he has got Margot, drags her to the front with astonishment, then retires, she following —Ninette hides her face in her hands, and gets to L.H. of Fuzee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why, what the deuce is all this?

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: What do I see?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Which way did you all get in here?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (shewing the back door)I came in by the little door.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: This has certainly been a well guarded prison; but, as everything is arranged, I hope we shall have no further occasion for it. (looks at Leon and Victor) I'm astonished! You are both so much alike, I'm now uncertain which is my son. (to Leon) Is it you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Hang me if I know whose son I am! Farmer Jacquard, or my old nurse, at Merrival, may be able to tell you. I'm totally ignorant of the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Farmer Jacquard?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The certificate that was sent me is now in the hands of the Brigadier.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You, then, are my son?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Are you my father? Bless your old physiognomy! If you only keep as good a table as my late father there, the inn-keeper, I shall consider you the best of fathers.

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Don't have him Leon—stick to the tavern-keeper. Stop, stop—perhaps he'll father me—I want a father.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Eh? let me see. The certificate was found by the Burgomaster in this soldier's pocket-book. (pointing to Victor)

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We slept last night in the same room. I, in the dark, took the wrong haversack.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: And in the one, were my son's pocket-book and my letter to him.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Because he had taken my haversack.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Then you are my son. Oh, my dear boy! pardon the mistake!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: All is forgotten in your arms! (they embrace)

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Then my brother is not my brother. How happy I am!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: So am I. The impostor is not an impostor. How delightful!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (to Leon.)But why did you assume my name?Ber. and Gav.Aye, why did you assume his name?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: (going on his knees between Berguin and Gavard) I'm the culprit. In me, behold the demon who has caused all this confusion. The madness, the name, everything originated with me. 'Twas the pangs of an empty stomach that drove me to the desperate deed: but as that is appeased, I hope you'll be so too: and as I am sadly in want of a father, perhaps both of you—(to Gavard and Berguin)— will father me between you.

sp.speaker: Gav.
sp.p: Aye, aye, you shall be taken care of. Fuzee rises, and retires at back to R.H. —Here, my son, is your sister. (introduces Ninette to Victor, who crosses past Margot)

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And here, my boy, is yours. (introduces Rosine to Leon) And now, as I see you all pretty well understand each other, change partners—cast off two couples—and go down the merry dance of matrimony, you rogues!

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: (passing to Rosine)My dear Rosine!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: (passing to Ninette)My dear Ninette! As for my prize in the lottery, that shall be divided between my wife and sister. And as for you, Fuzee—(crosses past him)

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: Gently—gently! I've some friends here, (pointing to bottles in R.H. corner) that I shouldn't like to have trod upon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: (L.H.)Then it was you who took the wine I missed?

sp.speaker: Fuzee.
sp.p: I was anxious to preserve a slip of such excellent vintage, to drink all your healths, as something whispered to me we should wind-up with a jollification.

sp.speaker: Coc.
sp.p: But who's to recompense me for my assault and battery?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: That, my nephew, must be your wedding present.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And now, having really found a father, (crosses to Ninette —Berguin crosses past Gavard—they meet in C.) all I wish for is, a kind and friendly circle of acquaintance to receive me and my dear Ninette. (to Audience) If your smiles beam a welcome on me and my comrades, all our efforts shall be directed to make us worthy of your friendship. And I trust you will never regret having received with favour THE BOLD DRAGOONS.

lg.head: >FINALE.
lg.l: Yet our efforts are not vain,
The Bold Dragoons mount guard again!

div.stage: Fuzee. Mar. Nin. Leon. Ber. Gav. Vic. Ros. Cocklet.
